name: megaptera-novaeangliae
definition: A baleen whale that arches its back when it dives, has long knobby flippers and a small dorsal fin, and communicates with complex songs.
description:
The humpback whale is a species of baleen whale.

One of the larger whale species, adults range in length from 12 to 16 m and weigh around 25 to 30 metric tons.

They are distinguished from other whales because of their large flippers, which are almost one-third the length of their body, and a hump on their backs.

Their color ranges from gray to black, with white markings on their belly.

Humpbacks dive to about 200 meters.

They can stay underwater for 30 minutes, but on average their dives only last about 15 minutes.

Humpback whales inhabit all major oceans from sub-polar latitudes to the equator.

Humpbacks live at the ocean's surface, both in shallow coastline waters and the open ocean.

They migrate seasonally from the warm tropical waters where breeding and calving takes place, to feeding areas in Arctic waters.

Humpback whales typically migrate up to 25,000 kilometers each year.

They feed in polar waters, and migrate to tropical or subtropical waters to breed and give birth, fasting and living off their fat reserves.

Their diet consists mostly of krill and small fish.

Humpbacks have a diverse repertoire of feeding methods, including the bubble net technique.

Transient killer whales prey on marine mammals, and are one of the humpback whale's main predators.

They attack calves and younger animals more frequently, and most humpback whales have scars as a result of prior orca attacks, including drag marks on their tails.

Humpbacks are polygynous, and the males compete aggressively for mating access to females.

They breed during winter in tropical waters. After gestation of 11.5 months, one calf is born.

Females must feed their calves around 45 kg of milk every day for 5 to 7 months until weaning, and calves may remain with their mothers for as much as a year.

Mothers are affectionate and protective towards their calves, swimming nearby and often touching their babies with their flippers.

Male humpbacks do not give parental support for calves.

These whales are sexually mature when they are 4 to 5 years old, and the birthing interval is 2 years.

It is known for breaching and other distinctive surface behaviors, making it popular with whale watchers.

Males produce a complex song lasting 10 to 20 minutes, which they repeat for hours at a time.

All the males in a group will produce the same song which is different each season.

Like other large whales, the humpback was a target for the whaling industry.

Once hunted to the brink of extinction, its population fell by an estimated 90% before a 1966 moratorium.

While stocks have partially recovered to some 80,000 animals worldwide, entanglement in fishing gear, collisions with ships and noise pollution continue to affect the species.

facts.name: Very large flippers
facts.value: Humpback whales have very large flippers that can reach the length of one third of their body size.

facts.name: Baby usually has 3 to 4.2 meters
facts.value: Baby usually has 3 to 4.2 meters in length and can weigh up to one ton at birth. It depends on mother's milk during the first five to seven months. Milk is rich in fat and enables fast growth of the young whale. Baby drinks 45 litres of milk per day.

facts.name: Pregnancy lasts 12 months
facts.value: Pregnancy lasts 12 months and ends up with single baby. Female gives birth every 2 to 3 years.

facts.name: Live between 45 and 50 years in the wild
facts.value: Humpback whales live between 45 and 50 years in the wild.

facts.name: Humpback whales are filter feeders
facts.value: Humpback whales are filter feeders. They swallow large amount of sea water and filter the food out of it by using baleen plates (which look like a huge comb) attached to their upper and lower jaw.

facts.name: Humpback whales are very large animals
facts.value: Humpback whales are very large animals. They weigh up to 48 tons which equals the weight of 4 adult elephants. Humpback whales reach 40 to 50 feet in length. Females are slightly larger.

facts.name: Eat small crustaceans and fishes
facts.value: Despite their large size, humpback whales eat one of the smallest animals in the ocean: krill (small crustaceans) and fish.

facts.name: Often jump out of the water
facts.value: Humpback whales often jump out of the water and splash the water's surface using the tails and flippers. Scientists believe that this behavior plays a role in communication between whales.

facts.name: Humpback whales are slow swimmers
facts.value: Humpback whales are slow swimmers. They usually swim 3-9 miles per hour, but they can reach up to 16.5 miles per hour when they are at danger.

facts.name: Mating takes place during the winter
facts.value: Mating of humpback whales usually takes place during the winter or early in the spring, in tropical (warm) oceans.

facts.name: One ton of food per day
facts.value: Humpback whale requires one ton of food per day.

facts.name: Songs for communication
facts.value: Another, more important, type of communication is a song characteristic for male humpback whales. Each population of humpback whales has unique song, which is used to attract females during mating season.

facts.name: Black belly with back and white markings
facts.value: Humpback whales usually have grey or black back and white markings on their bellies. White markings are unique (just like fingerprints), and researchers use them for identification of different individuals.

facts.name: Song can be heard on 30 kilometers
facts.value: Song of humpback whales can be heard on a distance of 30 kilometers.

facts.name: Hump on the back seen on water surface
facts.value: Name "humpback" originates from the hump on the back that can be seen every time they perform acrobatics on the water surface.

related.definition: The blue whale  is a marine mammal belonging to the baleen whale parvorder, Mysticeti.
A very large toothed whale formerly hunted for the spermaceti in its massive head and the ambergris in its intestines.
The killer whale or orca  is a toothed whale belonging to the oceanic dolphin family, of which it is the largest member.
The common minke whale is a species of minke whale within the suborder of baleen whales.
The beluga whale   is an Arctic and sub-Arctic cetacean.
The fin whale , also known as finback whale or common rorqual and formerly known as herring whale or razorback whale, is a cetacean belonging to the parvorder of baleen whales.
Cuvier's beaked whale is the most widely distributed of all the beaked whales.
